title: How to format text on typophile
content:
A work in progress. I think something's a little buggy…

\< a \> = [Hamburgerfonts](http://web.archive.org/)

\< em \> = _Hamburgerfonts_

\< strong \> = **Hamburgerfonts**

\< cite \> = <cite>Hamburgerfonts</cite>

\< code \> = `Hamburgerfonts`

\< ul \> =

Hamburgerfonts

\< ol \> =

Hamburgerfonts

\< li \> =

- Hamburgerfonts

\< dl \> =

<dl>Hamburgerfonts</dl>

\< dt \> =

<dt>Hamburgerfonts</dt>

\< dd \> =

<dd>Hamburgerfonts</dd>
author: Chris Dean

comments.content: Thanks for this. I tried to use \< i \> yesterday, and discovered it got swallowed up. Only after posting did I realize that I should have tried \< em \>.

@christopher  
ul and dl are "container" HTML elements. That means they're designed to describe syntactically and encase other elements.  
UL means unordered list and holds LI - list items. It doesn't hold text on it's own.  
DL - same thing. Means definition list and holds dt and dd elements.  
The comments parser that Typophile uses is just guessing at what to with the text within a UL or DL tag but yet outside of a LI or DT or DD tag.

Regards,  
rich

So we have:
<dl>
Definition List
<dt>
Term being defined
<dd>
Definition of the term
The usage is something like: `
Term
Definition
` —Joel
